meta.title: PSN Account Recovery Guide
meta.description: Interactive step-by-step guide for recovering a compromised PlayStation Network account.

root.label: What is your situation?
root.detail: Select the scenario that best describes your current problem.

children.label: Hacked Account
children.detail: The slow recognition that you cannot login and that your Sony account is now owned by someone else, likely in another country. This guide walks you through the recovery process.

children.label: Start a recovery folder
children.detail: Create a folder for this recovery process. Make and copy into it screenshots of everything, Create a timeline text file. Record calls, if you make them. In a worst case scenario this log will become invaluable

children.label: Has the hacker contacted you?
children.detail: Some hackers will contact you suggesting you buy your own account back or make the transfer "official". Others operate silently.

children.label: Yes
children.detail: The hacker may suggest you sell to them to make it official, or offer similar schemes.

children.label: Do NOT reply to the hacker
children.detail: They can use your conversation against you. Any communication can be twisted to make it appear you voluntarily transferred or sold the account.

children.label: No
children.detail: The hacker has not reached out (yet). This may happen, he may wish to 'make it official' because 'you cannot get it back'. Do not engage in a conversation.

children.label: Recovery Steps — All Scenarios
children.detail: These steps apply regardless of whether the hacker has contacted you. Work through them in order.

children.label: Verify you have been logged out
children.detail: Check all your devices — consoles, mobile apps, web sessions. If any are still logged in, you may still have options to secure the account before the hacker completes the takeover.

children.label: Report any attached credit card
children.detail: Contact your bank or credit card provider immediately. Report the card that was linked to your PSN account as compromised. This prevents the hacker from making purchases on your card. Get a new card as the hacker now knows some information about the card that can be re-used later.

children.label: About email-bombing
children.detail: You may have been email bombed — flooded with hundreds of spam messages. Go back to the start of the endless spam emails and unwanted subscription sign ups and look for the notification they are trying to hide.

children.label: Find sony SMS notifications
children.detail: Look through your recent text messages for any notification from Sony that two-factor authentication has been removed from your account. Screenshot this if found — it's important evidence.

children.label: Look for all emails from Sony
children.detail: Search your inbox for all recent Sony/PlayStation emails. These contain critical evidence of what the hacker changed.

children.label: User-ID change email
children.detail: This confirms the hacker changed your sign-in ID (email). Screenshot this email.

children.label: Please verify e-mail
children.detail: If you see an email from Sony asking you to verify your current email address, do NOT click the verification link. This would confirm the hacker's email change and could make recovery harder.

children.label: About your PSN OG email
children.detail: Verify that you can still access the email address you originally used to create the PSN account. This will be important for the recovery process.

children.label: Do NOT attempt recovery yet
children.detail: Do not attempt self-account recovery using the latest email you had against the account. You will probably be recovering a bogus account and not your account. The hacker has changed the email on file, and may have created a decoy account using your email.

children.label: Contact Sony support
children.detail: Start a chat session or call Sony support. Hours are not 24/7, call PSN country support (this may not be your local Sony support if your PSN account was out of region) during their hours and inform them you suspect your account has been hacked:

children.label: How support calls go
children.detail: A sony support call requests your best contact email address. This does not have to be your account email — it is so they can send you information after the call or call survey.

children.label: Give them your account handle (PSN ID)
children.detail: Your PSN ID / online handle is vital. Note that any email you give them will probably pull up a bogus account (perhaps out of region), because the hacker has changed the email on record.

children.label: If support is immediately unhelpful
children.detail: If support immediately sounds unhelpful it's likely because their screen says the account is locked for security purposes (they will not confirm this to you). The account will have been locked by the hacker (who pretended to be you). Do not get annoyed, they are only following a script. Politely attempt to escalate and get a case number. (This probably will not work on the first attempt).

children.label: Note the case number
children.detail: Get and record the case number from your call. It is unlikely to help directly, but it marks that the call happened and creates a record in Sony's system.

children.label: Report to gov consumer authorities
children.detail: You will now need to raise a case with the appropriate consumer authorities to get a better response from Sony. This is often the step that actually produces results.

children.label: Select your region
children.detail: The reporting authority depends on your PSN account region.

children.label: US — Report to the BBB
children.detail: File a complaint with the Better Business Bureau (BBB). Sony tends to respond to BBB complaints with more urgency than direct support requests.

children.label: Australia — Report to Fair Trading
children.detail: File a complaint with Fair Trading (NSW) or similar. Even if your account is not Aus/NZ, do this as you are an australian resident customer.

children.label: Europe — Report to consumer protection
children.detail: For European region, file a complaint with your national consumer protection agency or ombudsman.

children.label: What to include in your report
children.detail: Attach as much supporting documentation as possible.

children.label: Your identification
children.detail: if the report makes has a clear opportunity to provide ID that is not publiuc, upload ID such as passport or drivers license

children.label: Copy of a credit card transactions
children.detail: Showing transactions linked to the PSN account reinforces that you are the account holder.

children.label: A copy of a Sonys own transaction invoice email
children.detail: Any purchase confirmation or receipt from PlayStation Store you have in your inbox.

children.label: Keep file sizes small
children.detail: Note that the BBB attachment system is poor, so keep file sizes small. Compress images if needed.

children.label: Write a summary detailing the issue
children.detail: Include a clear narrative covering the key facts.

children.label: Date the account was originally created/obtained
Date and time the account was lost
Date of call to Sony support and unsatisfactory reply
Approximate value of games attached to the account
Your contact information and email address
Resolution outcome
children.detail: What happens next depends on whether Sony can resolve your case.

children.label: Resolution successful
children.detail: For all scenarios, resolution is unlikely on first-line support. You'll need a callback from the account restoration department. When they call, you will not be provided with a way to call them back.

children.label: Reverting of account to your email
children.detail: Sony may revert the account to your last known email and generate a recovery message. This is unlikely due to the account being flagged.

children.label: Reverting of account to OG email
children.detail: Sony may want to revert to your original email address due to "flags on the account". This may take them two steps as the hacker may have created a bogus account on that old email address.

children.label: Sony may not be able to generate recovery emails
children.detail: Their email system (Salesforce) may have blocked your specific email address due to past bounces. Request that a block be checked for, and lifted.

children.label: Ask how to lock the account for changes
children.detail: If offered, or if you are speaking to the restoration group, ask how to lock the account for changes. But don't forget — you don't want to lock it with an email the hacker already knows.

children.label: Change the account email
children.detail: Change the email address on record to one you possess that is known only to you. Consider using the +alias trick (e.g. yourname+xyz@email.com) or a completely new email address or domain. You have to coordinate out how to do this before a security lock is applied by Sony.

children.label: Use a passkey
children.detail: Sony recommend a passkey is used over two-factor. Sony does not support both passkey and two-factor

children.label: Change the security answer
children.detail: Not that this appears to be actively used by Sony, but change it regardless.

children.label: Do not re-attach the old credit card
children.detail: Replace the credit card against the account. Get a new card number from your bank, don't just re-add the same card.

children.label: Audit your own security for leaks
children.detail: Audit your own devices and accounts for any password leaks, or worse. You do not want to have been hacked through losing your own device security. Check haveibeenpwned.com and review all your password reuse.

children.label: Resolution unsuccessful
children.detail: Sony may reject the case. For the BBB that will be communicated by an emailed event from the BBB saying this and checking off a reason.

children.label: Refresh the consumer complaint
children.detail: Re-open the case, but provide more complete informaton.

children.label: Include more documentation of account ownership
children.detail: Provide any additional proof that you own the account — older purchase receipts, trophy history screenshots, etc.

children.label: Banned for abuse?
children.detail: The cherry on the cake: A week after restoration, your account may be "banned for abuse".

children.label: A hacker time-bomb
children.detail: The hacker sent abusive content from your PSN account to other accounts they control in order to trigger the ban later. This is a tactic to make the account perma-banned to punish the original owner for not 'dealing'. They may report your account repeatedly over 30, 60 and beyond day periods to generate escalating bans.

children.label: Appeal the ban
children.detail: TBA

children.label: Back to consumer affairs
children.detail: TBA

children.label: List dates and proof the account was hacked
children.detail: Use the timeline log you've been keeping to show the account was under someone else's control during the period the abuse occurred.

children.label: Include all previous contact with Sony
children.detail: Attach case numbers, call dates, and any email correspondence from the entire recovery process.

children.label: The process may take a week or more
children.detail: But your account may be restored after investigation.

children.label: The abuse happened while you were not in control
children.detail: The key point is that the abuse will have been sent during the time the account was not in your control. This is where the documented history and timeline you've been keeping comes in.

children.label: What does NOT work to "secure" your account
children.detail: These actions alone are insufficient if your account has been compromised.

children.label: Changing your handle to a non-valuable one
children.detail: Sony allow reversion back to the original, valuable, handle. This means your account will always be a target even if you change your PSN handle to a long one.

children.label: Changing just your password
children.detail: Your account was probably taken over without the hacker even knowing your password. A new password is insufficient security.

children.label: Adding back two-factor SMS login
children.detail: SMS-based 2FA can be bypassed social engineering using fragments of your identity on a support call. It's better than nothing but not sufficient as a sole security measure after a compromise. Sony recommend an authenticator app or passkey over two-factor SMS.

children.label: Forgot Password
children.detail: Go through the sign-in password reset process, the reset link will require the birthdate you entered when you first set up the account.

children.label: Forgot the fake birthday date?
children.detail: PSN linked accounts (EA, for example) will have copied your birthday to their profile for you! Get access to your linked account and discover the birthday it stored.

children.label: Last resort: contact Sony support
children.detail: Sony support may reset the birthday on your account, but only the account restoration group has this ability. Standard first-line support cannot do this — you may need to ask for escalation.
